name: Need for Cognition Scale
description: An 18-item scale measuring the tendency for an individual to engage in and enjoy thinking. People high in need for cognition are more likely to form attitudes based on careful assessment of relevant information.
reference: Cacioppo, J. T., Petty, R. E., & Kao, C. F. (1984). The efficient assessment of need for cognition. Journal of Personality Assessment, 48(3), 306-307.
instructions: For each of the statements below, please indicate to what extent the statement is characteristic of you.

questions.name: nfc_1
questions.description: I would prefer complex to simple problems.

questions.name: nfc_2
questions.description: I like to have the responsibility of handling a situation that requires a lot of thinking.

questions.name: nfc_3
questions.description: Thinking is not my idea of fun.

questions.name: nfc_4
questions.description: I would rather do something that requires little thought than something that is sure to challenge my thinking abilities.

questions.name: nfc_5
questions.description: I try to anticipate and avoid situations where there is likely a chance I will have to think in depth about something.

questions.name: nfc_6
questions.description: I find satisfaction in deliberating hard and for long hours.

questions.name: nfc_7
questions.description: I only think as hard as I have to.

questions.name: nfc_8
questions.description: I prefer to think about small, daily projects to long-term ones.

questions.name: nfc_9
questions.description: I like tasks that require little thought once I've learned them.

questions.name: nfc_10
questions.description: The idea of relying on thought to make my way to the top appeals to me.

questions.name: nfc_11
questions.description: I really enjoy a task that involves coming up with new solutions to problems.

questions.name: nfc_12
questions.description: Learning new ways to think doesn't excite me very much.

questions.name: nfc_13
questions.description: I prefer my life to be filled with puzzles that I must solve.

questions.name: nfc_14
questions.description: The notion of thinking abstractly is appealing to me.

questions.name: nfc_15
questions.description: I would prefer a task that is intellectual, difficult, and important to one that is somewhat important but does not require much thought.

questions.name: nfc_16
questions.description: I feel relief rather than satisfaction after completing a task that required a lot of mental effort.

questions.name: nfc_17
questions.description: It's enough for me that something gets the job done; I don't care how or why it works.

questions.name: nfc_18
questions.description: I usually end up deliberating about issues even when they do not affect me personally.
